raw_text:
Navratilova hits out at critics
 
 Martina Navratilova has defended her decision to prolong her tennis career at the age of 48.
 
 Navratilova, who made a comeback after retiring in 1994, will play doubles and mixed doubles events in 2005. "Women's tennis is really strong," she said, dismissing suggestions that the fact she could still win reflected badly on the women's game. "All I can say is I'm that damn good. I'm sorry but I really have to blow my own horn here. I'm still that good." Navratilova has won three Grand Slam mixed doubles titles since she came out of retirement. And she was so encouraged by her form that she decided to resume playing singles, winning two of her seven matches. She was knocked out in the first round of the French Open but reached the second round at Wimbledon. Navratilova will partner Nathalie Dechy in the doubles event at the Uncle Toby's Hardcourts tournament on Australia's Gold Coast, which begins on Sunday. She will then link up with Daniela Hantuchova for the Australian Open doubles, and play in the mixed doubles with Leander Paes. "I might be playing some singles events this season, depending on the surface," she added.

She plans to play in doubles and mixed doubles events this season, including the Australian Open, after winning three Grand Slam mixed doubles titles since coming out of retirement.

She has three Grand Slam mixed doubles titles since retiring in 1994. She won two singles matches, got knocked out in the French Open, and played in the Wimbledon finals. She’s also planning to play doubles at the Australian Open against Daniela Hantuchova and Leander Paes on Australia's Gold Coast.

Martina Navratilova defended her decision to play doubles in 2005, dismissing criticism that an age could reflect too much on women's tennis. She has three Grand Slam mixed doubles titles since retiring, won two singles matches, was knocked out in the French Open, and played in Wimbledon finals. She plans to compete at the Australian Open doubles against Daniela Hantuchova and Leander Paes on Australia's Gold Coast, along with possibly some singles events due to the surface conditions.

Navratiloova has confirmed that she will participate in the doubles events at Australia's Gold Coast, including partnering with Daniela Hantuchova for the Australian Open doubles and playing in the mixed doubles with Leander Paes.
